name: Dugong
about: Commonly known as sea cows, Dugongs are marine mamals that graze peacefully on sea grasses in shallow coastal waters of the Indian and western Pacific Oceans. Their numbers are threatened by sea grass habitat loss or degradation due to coastal development or industrial activities that cause water pollution.

name: Sumatran tigers
about: This tiger subspecies is found exclusively on the Indonesian island of Sumatra. They are the smallest surving subspecies, distunguished by their heavy black stripes. Accelerating deforestation and rampant poaching are the main reasons for their near extinction.

name: Amur Leopard
about: Also known as the Manchurian or Korean leopard, the Amur leopard are a subspecies that lives in the Russian Far East.The greatest threats to their sustainabilty are prey scarcity and illegal poaching.

name: Narwhal
about: Narwhals look like a cross between a whale and unicorn with a long spiraled tusk jutting from its head. They spend their lives in the Arctic waters of Canada, Greenland, Norway, and Russia. Climate change is the greatest threat to conservation along with oil and gas development and ocean noise.

name: Borneo Pygmy Elephant
about: The pygmy elephants of Borneo are baby-faced with oversized ears, plump bellies and long tails. They are genetically different than other Asian elephants and gentler than their counterparts. The smallest elephants in Asia, the greatest threats to their survival are conlflict with humans and habitat loss.

name: Bonobo
about: Bonobos look like chimpanzees but are usually smaller, leaner, darker, and less understood. They are gentler than chimpanzees and led by females. Poaching and habitat loss from the civil unrest in the region are the leading causes of rapid population decline.

name: Greater sage-grouse
about: Iconic large birds in western U.S. and Canada, the Greater sage-grouse were once found across 13 western U.S states and 3 Canadian provinces. They are known for their spectacular mating dances; howecer, the oil and gas development, land conversion for agriculture, and climate change, these magnificent birds are facing a rapid decline.

name: Mountain Gorilla
about: The mountain gorillas live in forests high inthe mountains, at elevations of 8,000 to 13,000 feet. They are the world's smaleest population of mountain gorillas and have been pushed farther north to uninhabitable conditions because of civil unrest, habitat loss, and poaching.

name: Marine iguana
about: Marine iguanas are the world's only oceangoing lizard and only found in the Galápagos. The marine iguanas reside on a central tourist beach in Perto Villamil on Isabel Island, sharing their home with tourists. As more people move to the island, the largest threat are introduced species like cats and dogs, along with climate change.

name: Sumatran rhinos
about: Smallest of the rhinos, they are the only Asian rhino with two horns and most closely related to the extinct woolly rhinos. These rhinos are so rare and elusive that even the most senior rangers have never seen the animal in the wild. The illegal wildlife trade, habitat loss, and lack of protection are the greatest factor for the endangerment.

name: Kagu
about: Found on Grand Terre, the largest and moutainous island of New Caledonia, the Kagu is a rare and flightless bird that is the only surviving species of its taxonomic family. The Kagu's startling ash-white plumage has given them the nickname 'ghost of the forest.' They have a distinct 'bark' that can be heard over a mile away. Dogs and predation by introduced species like cats, pigs, and rats, along with habitat loss are the greatest threat to Kagu existence.

name: African Wild Dogs
about: One of the world's most endangered mammals, wild dogs gather in packs of about 10 to 40. Largest populations remain in southern Africa and southern part of East Africa, especially Tanzania and northern Mozambique. Kilings by humans, viral disease, habitat loss, and competition with larger predators are reasons for their dwindling population.

name: Saola
about: Only discovered 26 years ago in May 1992, Saola have two parallel horns with sharp ends, which can reach 20 inches in length. Exclusive to the Annamite Mountains of Vietnam and Laos, they are extremely rare. Hunting, habitat loss, and deforestastion from rapid and large-scale modernization are the main reasons for their dwindling numbers.

name: Black-footed Ferret
about: Once thought extinct, the black-footed ferrets are making a comeback. They are the only ferret species native to North America. Although conservation efforts are helping revive their population, habitat loss and non-native disease still remain key threats to their survival.

name: Hector's Dolphins
about: Hector's dolphins are the smallest and rarest marine dolphins. They have distinct black facial markings, short stocky bodies, and dorsal fin shaped like Mickey Mouse ears. Only found in the shallow coastal waters along the western shores of North Island, bycatch is the biggest problem for the dolphins, along with, pollution in their habiats, and coastal development.

name: Red Panda
about: Recognized by their thick russet fur and white facial markings, red pandas are very skillful and acrobatic animals that predominantly stay in trees. Climate change and loss of nesting trees are the greatest cause of decline in population, along with poaching.

name: Grevy's Zebra
about: Taller than the plains zebras, Grevy's sebra also have larger ears and narrower stripes than plains zebras. Extreme habitat loss and hunting are the primary causes for their decline.

name: Central American River Turtle
about: These nocturnal reptiles are the sole surviving species and can trace their lineage back to the time of dinosaurs. The Central American River turtle is completely aquatic and feeds on plant matter. They are highly coveted for their tasty meat, so overexploitation, coupled with rapid loss of habitat are the reasons for their near extinction.

name: North Atlantic Right Whale
about: The North Atlantic right whale can easily be identified by the white calluses on its head. They are now mostly found along the Atlantic coast of North America. A long history of human exploitation, climate change, and ocean noise are the greatest threat to their existence

name: Cross River Gorilla
about: Very similar to the western lowland gorilla, the Cross River gorillas live in an area that is heavily populated by humans. Hunting, inbreeding, and rapid loss of habitat are the main reasons for their endangerment.
